And just as the essences of creation are substance and accident, and the Essence of Allah is sanctified from that and does not correspond to what is not substance and accidentâ€”substance and accidentâ€”so too His attributes do not correspond to the attributes of creation. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
Indeed, a condition was set for him of a wage upon it, and the One Who set the condition is Generous [karim], fulfilling the promise whatever He promises, and does not break it, but rather increases. So the hired worker came and broke the vessels and ruined them all, then sat awaiting the wage, claiming that the employer is generous. Would the people of intellect see him in his waiting as one who is hopeful [raji] or as one who is deluded [maghrur]? This is from ignorance of the distinction between hope [raja'] and delusion [ghurra]. It was said to Al-Hasan: "A people say, 'We hope in God,' yet they neglect the work." He said: "Far be it, far be it! Those are their wishes [amaniyyah] they are swayed by. Whoever hopes for a thing seeks it, and whoever fears a thing flees from it." And Muslim ibn Yasar said: "Last night I prostrated until my front teeth fell out!" A man said to him: "Indeed, we hope in God!" Muslim said: "Far be it, far be it? Whoever hopes for a thing seeks it, and whoever fears a thing flees from it." And just as he who hopes in the world [dunya] for a child, yet he has not married, or married but has not had intercourse, or had intercourse but has not emitted, he is foolish. Likewise, he who hopes for the mercy of God, yet he has not believed, or believed but has not done righteous deeds, or done them but has not abandoned sins, he is deluded [maghrur]. And just as when he marries, has intercourse, and emits, he remains in a state of uncertainty regarding the child, fearing and hoping for the grace [fadl] of God in creating the child and warding off afflictions from the womb and from the mother until it is complete, he is wise [kayyis]. Likewise, when he believes and does righteous deeds and abandons evil deeds, and remains in a state of uncertainty between fear [khawf] and hope [raja'], fearing that it will not be accepted from him and that he will not remain steadfast upon it and that his end will be sealed with evil, and hoping in God, the Exalted, that He will establish him with the firm word [al-qawl al-thabit] and protect his religion from the thunderbolts of the agonies of death until he dies upon monotheism [tawhid], and guards his heart [qalb] from inclining towards the desires for the rest of his life so that he does not incline towards sins, he is wise [kayyis]. And whoever is other than these, they are the ones deluded [maghrur] by God. "And they will know, when they see the punishment, who is farthest astray in way. And you will know the tidings of it after a time." And at that time they will say, as God has informed about them: "Our Lord, we have seen and we have heard, so return us, we will do righteous deeds. Indeed, we are certain [muqinun]." That is, we have learned that just as a child is not born except by intercourse and marriage, and a crop does not sprout except by tilling and sowing seed, likewise, reward and wage are not attained in the Hereafter [akhirah] except by righteous deeds. So return us, we will do righteous deeds, for we have now learned the truth of Your saying: "And that for man is only what he has striven for, and that his striving is going to be seen. Every time a company is thrown into it, its keepers will ask them, 'Did there not come to you a warner?' They will say, 'Yes, a warner had come to us.'" That is, did we not hear you regarding the way of God [sunnat Allah] with His servants, and that "Every soul will be paid in full what it has earned," and that "Every soul, for what it has earned, is held in pledge"? So what deluded you [gharra] concerning God after you had heard and understood? "They will say, 'If only we had been listening or reasoning, we would not be among the companions of the Blaze.' So they will acknowledge their sin. Then, away with the companions of the Blaze!"

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
Indeed they will say, "If only we had been listening [sami'na] or reasoning [na'qilu], we would not be among the companions of the Blaze [ashab al-sa'ir]." So they acknowledged their sin. Then, away with the companions of the Blaze! If you ask: "Then where is the place of hope [raja'] and its praiseworthy location?" Know that it is praiseworthy in two places: The first: For the disobedient one who is immersed [in sin], when the thought of repentance [tawba] occurs to him, and Satan says to him, "How could your repentance be accepted?" causing him to despair [yaqnutu] of the mercy of Allah, the Exalted. At this point, it is necessary to suppress that despair with hope [raja'] and to remember, "Indeed, Allah forgives all sins," and that Allah is Generous, accepting repentance from His servants, and that repentance is an act of obedience that expiates sins. Allah, the Exalted, says, "Say, 'O My servants who have transgressed against themselves, do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful.' And turn to your Lord [rabbikum]." He commanded them to turn [inaba]. And He, the Exalted, says, "And indeed, I am Forgiving to whoever repents and believes and does righteous work and then continues in guidance." So, if he anticipates forgiveness [maghfira] along with repentance, he is one who hopes [raji]. But if he anticipates forgiveness while persisting [in sin], he is deluded [maghrur]. It is like one for whom the time for Friday prayer has become tight while he is in the market, and the thought occurs to him to hasten to the Friday prayer. Satan says to him, "You will not catch the prayer," so he should remain in his place. If he rejects Satan's lie and goes running, hoping to catch the Friday prayer, he is one who hopes. But if he continues with his trade and begins to hope that the Imam will delay the prayer for his sake until the middle of the time, or for the sake of another, or for some reason he does not know, he is deluded. The second: When his soul [nafs] becomes sluggish concerning the virtues of deeds [fada'il al-a'mal] and he confines himself to the obligatory duties [fara'id], he should inspire hope in his soul for the bliss [na'im] of Allah, the Exalted, and what He has promised the righteous, so that from that hope [raja'] a vigor for worship [nashat al-'ibada] may spring forth, and he turns to the virtues. And he should remember the saying of Allah, the Exalted, "Certainly will the believers have succeeded: They who are during their prayer humbly submissive" up to His saying, "Those are the inheritors who will inherit Paradise, wherein they will abide eternally." Thus, the first hope suppresses the despair that prevents repentance. The second hope suppresses the sluggishness [futur] that prevents vigor and exertion [tashammur]. So, every anticipation that urges towards repentance or towards exertion in worship is hope [raja']. And every hope that causes sluggishness in worship and complacency in idleness is delusion [ghurra], just as when the thought occurs to him to abandon sin and engage in worship, Satan says to him, "What is it to you, harming and tormenting yourself? You have a Lord who is Generous, Forgiving, Merciful." So he becomes sluggish because of that regarding repentance and worshipâ€”that is delusion. a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Meditation
And when you know the path of thought (Fikr) in your self (Nafs), then contemplate the earth which is your abode, then in its rivers and mountains and its plains, then ascend from it to the dominion (Malakut) of the heavens. As for the earth, from His signs is that He created the earth as a bed (Firash) and a resting place (Mahad), and made in it wide paths, and made it submissive (Dhulul) so that you may walk in its tracts, and made it stable so it does not move, and set in it mountains as pegs for it to prevent it from shaking, then expanded its expanses until the sons of Adam (Adam) were unable to reach all its sides even if their lifespans were long and their travels abundant. So He, the Exalted, said: 'And the heaven We constructed with strength, and indeed, We are [its] expander. And the earth We have spread out, and excellent is the preparer.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'He is the one who made for you the earth submissive (Dhulul), so walk in its tracts.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'The one who made for you the earth a bed (Firash).' And He has frequently mentioned the earth in His mighty book so that one may contemplate its wonders: its surface is an abode for the living and its interior is a resting place for the dead. He, the Exalted, said: 'Have We not made the earth a container, for the living and the dead?' So look at the earth when it is dead, then when water is sent down upon it, it quivers and swells and greens and produces wonders of plants, and from it emerge various kinds of animals.

And whoever takes the meanings from the names thinks that these states are different in their essences and realities because the names appear different. But the one who follows the straight path and looks with the light of Allah (God) observes the meanings first, then perceives their realities, then notices the names, for they were established as indicators of the meanings. For the disbelievers did not err in what they erred in except by such reversals. We ask Allah for good success through His generosity and kindness.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
And the variation in the composition of its limbs is wonders that increase upon wonders in its resurrection and restoration, so how can one deny that from the power (Qudrah) of Allah the Exalted and His wisdom who witnesses that in His creation and power? If there is weakness in your faith (Iman), then strengthen the faith (Iman) by looking at the first creation, for the second is like it and easier than it. And if you are strong in faith (Iman) in it, then make your heart (Qalb) feel those fears and dangers, and increase in it reflection (Tafakkur) and consideration (I'tibar) to strip from your heart (Qalb) comfort and settlement, so you become occupied with preparing for the presentation before the Compeller (Al-Jabbar). And reflect first on what strikes the hearing of the inhabitants of the graves from the intensity of the blowing of the Trumpet (As-Sur), for it is a single cry by which the graves split open from the heads of the dead, and they rise up all at once. So imagine yourself having sprung up with your face changed, your body dusty from the parting of your hair to your feet from the dust of your grave, bewildered from the intensity of the shock, with your eye fixed toward the call. And the creation has risen up in a single uprising from the graves in which their tribulation (Bala') has been prolonged, and they have been agitated by terror (Faza') and dread (Ru'b), added to what was with them of sorrows (Humum) and griefs (Ghumum) and intense waiting for the outcome of the matter, as Allah the Exalted said: 'And the Trumpet (As-Sur) will be blown, and all who are in the heavens and all who are on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And when the Trumpet (An-Naqur) is blown, that Day will be a difficult day for the disbelievers; not easy.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And they say, "When is this promise, if you should be truthful?" They do not await except one blast which will seize them while they are disputing. And they will not be able to make a testament, nor to their people can they return. And the Trumpet (As-Sur) will be blown, and at once from the graves to their Lord they will hasten. They will say, "O woe to us! Who has raised us from our sleeping place? This is what the Most Merciful had promised, and the messengers told the truth."' So if there were not before the dead except the terror of that blowing, it would be worthy of being feared, for it is a blowing and a cry by which those in the heavens and the earth are struck dead, meaning they die by it except whom Allah wills, and that is some of the angels. And therefore the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'How can I be at ease when the possessor of the Trumpet (As-Sur) has taken the horn in his mouth, lowered his forehead, and inclined his ear, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow?' Maqatil said: The Trumpet (As-Sur) is the horn, and that is because Israfil (upon him be peace) has placed his mouth on the horn like the form of a trumpet, and the circle of the head of the horn is like the expanse of the heavens and the earth, and he is fixing his gaze toward the Throne (Al-'Arsh), waiting for when he will be commanded to blow the first blowing. And when he blows, those in the heavens and the earth are struck dead, meaning every animal dies from the intensity of the terror except whom Allah wills, and that is Jibril, Mika'il, Israfil, and the Angel of Death (Malak al-Mawt). Then the Angel of Death (Malak al-Mawt) is commanded to take the soul (Ruh) of Jibril, then the soul (Ruh) of Mika'il, then the soul (Ruh) of Israfil, then the Angel of Death (Malak al-Mawt) is commanded and he dies. Then the creation remains after the first blowing in the Intermediate State (Al-Barzakh) for forty years, then Allah the Exalted revives Israfil and commands.
